text: Man goeth forth unto his work and to his labour until the evening.
text_kjv: Man goeth forth unto his work and to his labour until the evening.
text_niv: Then man goes out to his work,to his labor until evening.
text_esv: Man goes out to his work and to his labor until the evening.
text_nlt: Then people go off to their work,where they labor until evening.
text_msg: Meanwhile, men and women go out to work,busy at their jobs until evening.
text_nasb: Man goes forth to his work And to his labor until evening.
context: Psalm 104 is a hymn celebrating God's creative power and providential care for the world. Understanding the historical and cultural context of Psalm 104:23, "Man goeth forth unto his work and to his labour until the evening," requires recognizing the agrarian society in which it was written. In ancient Israel, life revolved around agriculture and animal husbandry. The vast majority of people were farmers, shepherds, or craftsmen supporting these essential industries. Their days were dictated by the rising and setting of the sun. Sunrise marked the beginning of a long day of physical labor, often involving tilling the fields, planting seeds, harvesting crops, or tending livestock under the harsh Middle Eastern sun. The tools they used were basic and labor-intensive, requiring considerable physical strength and endurance. Labor was not merely a means of sustenance; it was intrinsically linked to survival. The evening offered respite and rest, a necessary reprieve from the day's toils. Furthermore, the rhythm of work and rest was tied to the liturgical calendar and the observance of Sabbaths and festivals, emphasizing the importance of balance and acknowledging God's provision. The verse reflects this reality, encapsulating the daily routine of the common Israelite, highlighting the dependence on God's blessings for a fruitful day of work. The psalm implicitly acknowledges the inherent dignity of labor, positioning it as a natural part of God's created order.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 104:23 speaks to several key concepts. First, it affirms the goodness of work as part of God's created order. It's not presented as a curse or punishment, but as a natural and necessary aspect of human life within God's design. The verse suggests that work is a purposeful activity, contributing to the sustenance and flourishing of both the individual and the community. It reflects God's own creative labor in forming the world and sustaining it. Second, the verse points to the reality of human limitations. The phrase "until the evening" acknowledges that human strength and energy are finite. It implicitly calls for a recognition of the need for rest and reliance on God to provide strength and sustenance. This reinforces the Sabbath principle, where rest is commanded as a weekly reminder of God's provision and our dependence on Him. Third, the verse can be interpreted as a reminder of God's providential care. While humans engage in labor, their efforts are ultimately dependent on God's blessing for success. Rain, sunlight, and fertile soil are all gifts from God that enable human work to bear fruit. Therefore, the verse is an invitation to acknowledge God's role in every aspect of life, including our work, and to approach labor with humility and gratitude. Finally, some theologians see in the verse a connection to the creation mandate in Genesis, where humanity is tasked with tending and keeping the Garden of Eden. Our work, in a sense, is a continuation of this mandate, reflecting God's creative activity and contributing to the stewardship of the earth.
application: In our modern context, Psalm 104:23 has profound implications for how we approach work. First, it challenges the often-held view that work is simply a means to an end, a way to accumulate wealth or achieve status. Instead, it encourages us to view work as a meaningful activity with inherent dignity, regardless of the specific job. Whether we are teachers, nurses, artists, or laborers, our work has value because it contributes to the well-being of society and reflects God's creative purpose. Second, the verse serves as a reminder to maintain a healthy work-life balance. In today's 24/7 culture, it is easy to become consumed by work, neglecting our physical, emotional, and spiritual needs. The phrase "until the evening" reminds us of the importance of setting boundaries, prioritizing rest, and making time for relationships, hobbies, and spiritual renewal. It challenges the glorification of overwork and encourages us to prioritize well-being. Third, the verse can inspire us to approach our work with a sense of purpose and service. Instead of focusing solely on personal gain, we can ask ourselves how our work can contribute to the common good. How can we use our skills and talents to make a positive difference in the lives of others? This perspective can transform even the most mundane tasks into meaningful acts of service. Fourth, the verse invites us to cultivate a spirit of gratitude for the opportunity to work. In a world where unemployment and underemployment are prevalent, having a job is a privilege. We can express our gratitude by approaching our work with diligence, integrity, and a positive attitude. Finally, it encourages us to seek God's guidance and blessing in our work. We can pray for wisdom, strength, and creativity, trusting that God will guide our efforts and use our work to accomplish His purposes. By integrating these principles into our daily lives, we can transform our work from a mere obligation into a source of meaning, fulfillment, and spiritual growth.
prayer: Gracious God, creator of all things, we thank you for the gift of work. We acknowledge that it is through your provision that we have the strength and opportunity to labor. Help us to approach our work with diligence, integrity, and a spirit of service. Remind us to maintain a healthy balance in our lives, recognizing the importance of rest and renewal. Grant us wisdom to use our skills and talents to make a positive difference in the world. Forgive us for the times when we have idolized work or neglected our relationships and our spiritual well-being. May our work be a reflection of your love and grace, and may it bring glory to your name. We ask this in the name of Jesus Christ, our Lord. Amen.

faqs.answer: While the verse affirms the general goodness of work as part of God's created order, it doesn't mean all types of work are equally pleasing to God. Work that is unethical, exploitative, or harmful to others would contradict God's principles of justice and love. The intention and impact of the work are crucial considerations.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Does this verse imply that all work is inherently good and pleasing to God?

faqs.answer: This verse implicitly supports the concept of Sabbath rest by acknowledging that human labor is finite and that "the evening" brings a natural end to the workday. It reinforces the need for regular periods of rest and reflection, mirroring the Sabbath principle of dedicating time to God and allowing for physical and spiritual restoration.

It affirms that work, regardless of its perceived status, has inherent value because it contributes to the well-being of both the individual and the community, reflecting God's own creative work.
